Award.AwardTitle: Readout Systems for Cryogenic Dark Matter Detectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays.

The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration has pioneered the use of low temperature phonon-mediated detectors to detect the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and distinguish them from backgrounds. This work will have a broad impact which extends beyond the dark matter search. The technical developments will further advance phonon-mediated detectors, which have already found many applications in science and technology.

This program, working with techniques on the leading edge of measurement technology, supports education and training of physics and electrical engineering undergraduate students in the PI's group, a diverse body including non-traditional and first-generation college students, as well as students from groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. The PI participates in the CU Denver's Mini-STEM school, the local CafÂ´e Scientifique, and a field trip program at a local K-8 magnet school.

This award will enable the PI and his students to fulfill specific responsibilities for both SuperCDMS Soudan and SuperCDMS SNOLAB projects, including operations support for SuperCDMS Soudan, superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) characterization and testing for SNOLAB, and support during construction and initial commissioning. Planned activities also include a modest R&D effort toward multiplexed SQUID readout, required for the next-generation dark matter direct detection efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to astronomical observations, approximately 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of ordinary particles, but exists in some as yet unknown form, which we call dark matter. Deciphering the nature of dark matter is of fundamental importance to several branches of science, including cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that dark matter comprises Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, produced moments after the Big Bang. Such particles would interact only through gravity and the weak nuclear force. If this hypothesis is correct, then the presence of WIMPs in our galaxy should be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in a terrestrial detector. The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration and its successor, the SuperCDMS Collaboration, have pioneered the use of low-temperature phonon-mediated devices to search for the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and to distinguish them from background interactions such as electron or gamma-ray scattering, which predominate.

This award provides support for the University of Colorado Denver (CU Denver) SuperCDMS group that, in conjunction with other SuperCDMS collaboration awards, will enable the SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment, a second-generation (G2) dark matter detector focusing on low-mass WIMPs. The silicon and germanium crystals that comprise the primary detectors for dark matter interactions are operated near absolute zero and each interaction produces a brief, tiny temperature rise. While most interactions are from the background (electrons and gamma rays), some should be WIMPs. These temperature fluctuations, related to phonons, are converted to small electric current pulses. These pulses are, in turn, amplified to produce signals that can be digitized and recorded by room temperature electronics. The primary device used in this conversion process is a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID), an extremely sensitive sensor of magnetic fields and electric currents. The SQUID and the room-temperature electronics form the basis of the readout system for this channel of dark matter interactions with the detectors. Integration of this preamplifier with the detector, cold hardware, and other room-temperature electronics is essential to the success of the experiment and falls within the expertise of the PI and the CU Denver group

This technical development will have the broader impact of extending the limits of phonon-mediated detectors. Phonon-mediated detectors have increasing utility in many areas of physics and astrophysics, from optical astronomy to x-rays and cosmic microwave backgrounds studies. The CU Denver group focuses on undergraduate participation, educating undergraduate students majoring in physics and electrical engineering in the use of techniques at the leading edge of measurement technologies and providing them a solid foundation in laboratory research.
